description: From Middle English tagge (“small piece hanging from a garment”), probably of North Germanic origin. Compare Norwegian tagg (“point; prong; barb; tag”), Swedish tagg (“thorn; prickle; tine”), Icelandic tág (“a willow-twig”). Compare also tack.

entries.meaning: A small label.
A children's chasing game in which one player (known as "it") attempts to touch another, who then becomes "it".
A skin tag, an excrescence of skin.
A type of cardboard.
Graffiti in the form of a stylized signature particular to the artist.
examples: There is a hierarchy of sorts: a throw-up can go over a tag, a piece over a throw-up, and a burner over a piece.

entries.meaning: A dangling lock of sheep's wool, matted with dung; a dung tag.
(informal, authorship) An attribution in narrated dialogue (eg, "he said") or attributed words (e.g. "he thought").
examples: Synonyms: dialogue tag, speech tag, tag line

entries.meaning: (music) The last line (or last two lines) of a song's chorus that is repeated to indicate the end of the song.
(television) The last scene of a TV program, often focusing on the program's subplot.
(chiefly US) A vehicle number plate; a medal bearing identification data (animals, soldiers).
examples: The subwoofer in the trunk was so loud, it vibrated the tag like an aluminum can.

entries.meaning: (baseball) An instance of touching the baserunner with the ball or the ball in a gloved hand to rule him "out."
examples: The tag was applied at second for the final out.

entries.meaning: (computing) A piece of markup representing an element in a markup language.
examples: The <title> tag provides a title for the Web page.
The <sarcasm> tag conveys sarcasm in Internet slang.

entries.meaning: (computing) A keyword, term, or phrase associated with or assigned to data, media, and/or information enabling keyword-based classification; often used to categorize content.
examples: I want to add genre and artist tags to the files in my music collection.

entries.meaning: Any slight appendage, as to an article of dress; something slight hanging loosely.
A metallic binding, tube, or point, at the end of a string, or lace, to stiffen it.
The end, or catchword, of an actor's speech; cue.
Something mean and paltry; the rabble.
A sheep in its first year.
(biochemistry) Any short peptide sequence artificially attached to proteins mostly in order to help purify, solubilize or visualize these proteins.
(slang) A person's name.

verbs.description: tag (third-person singular simple present tags, present participle tagging, simple past and past participle tagged)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To label (something).
(transitive, graffiti) To mark (something) with one’s tag.
(transitive) To remove dung tags from a sheep.
examples: Regularly tag the rear ends of your sheep.

entries.meaning: (transitive, baseball, colloquial) To hit the ball hard.
(transitive, vulgar, slang, 1990s) to have sex with someone (especially a man of a woman)
examples: Steve is dying to tag Angie from chemistry class.

entries.meaning: (transitive, baseball) To put a runner out by touching them with the ball or the ball in a gloved hand.
examples: He tagged the runner for the out.

entries.meaning: (transitive, computing) To mark with a tag (metadata for classification).
examples: I am tagging my music files by artist and genre.

entries.meaning: To follow closely, accompany, tag along.
examples: A tall young man came striding through the park along the path near which she sat. Behind him tagged a boy carrying a suit-case.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To catch and touch (a player in the game of tag).
(transitive) To fit with, or as if with, a tag or tags.
To fasten; to attach.
examples: they began to tag their law with the scraps of philofophy

description: Borrowed from Aramaic תגא‎ (“crown”). Doublet of taj.

entries.meaning: A decoration drawn over some Hebrew letters in Jewish scrolls.
